bibl.title: Peter Williamson Merta v. Henry M. White. Return and Answer of Respondent
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washinton
In the Matter of the application of Peter Williamson Murta, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Return and Answer of Respondent,Henry M.White, Commissioner of Immigration
Filed in the United States District Court
Return and Answer of Respondent, Henry M. White, Commissioner of Immigration.
In the Matter of the Application of Peter Williamson Merta, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus

Comes now the respondent herein, Henry M, White, Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington, and responding to the order to show cause heretofore entered by the court herein and answering the petition of the above named applicant for a Writ of Habeas Corpus herein respectfully certifies and shows to the Court as follows:
That this respondent denies each and every allegation of the petition or complaint herein of the above named applicant, Peter Williamson Merta, except as hereinafter admitted.
And this respondent further certifies and respectfully shows to the court as follows:
That Henry M. White is now and at all of the times mentioned herein and in the petitioner's complaint has been United States Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington.

That the said petitioner, Peter Williamson Merta (or Melta) alias Peter Williamson, alias Peter M. Williamson was duly and regularly arrested and detained under and by virtue of a warrant duly and regularly issued by the Secretary of Labor on the First day of March, 1918, commanding that said petitioner and alien be taken into custody and granted a hearing to enable him to show cause why he should not be deported in conformity with law upon the ground that said alien had been found in the United States advocating or teaching the unlawful destruction of property, which said warrant is included withing and shown as a part of Exhibit "A" hereinafter referred to and hereto attached and made a part hereof; that said petitioner ever since said day of arrest has been duly and regularly detained in custody under and by virtue of said warrant of arrest.

That on to-wit: April 30th, 1918, the said petitioner was duly and regularly examined by and had a hearing before Immigration Inspector Thomas M. Fisher, with relation to the matters and facts set forth in said warrant of arrest as aforesaid; that upon said hearing the said Immigration Inspector duly found that the said alien had been found in the United States advocating and teaching the unlawful destruction of property.

That on to-wit: the 30th day of November, 1918, the Commissioner of Immigration at Seattle, Washington, concurred in the said finding of the said Immigration Inspector and concurred in the recommendation made by the said Immigration Inspector upon said hearing that the said alien be deported.

That the said petitioner has had a full and fair hearing as provided by law and that a record of the proceedings had with relation to the arrest and deportation of said petitioner as aforesaid, including the transcript of testimony adduced in said proceedings and including the warrant of arrest, is hereto attached, marked Exhibit "A" and by reference made a part hereof.

That on the 13th day of December, 1918, a warrant was duly and regularly issued by the Secretary of Labor commanding the arrest and detention of said alien for deportation upon the ground that the said alien, the petitioner hereinabove named, had been found in the United States advocating or teaching the unlawful destruction of property and that the said alien has been found a member of or affiliated with an organization that entertains a belief in, teaches and advocates the overthrow by force or violence of the Government of the United States or of all forms or law or that entertain or teaches disbelief in or opposition to all organized Governments or that advocates the duty, necessity or propriety of the unlawful assault or killing of any officer or officers either of specific individuals or of officers generally of the Government of the United States or any other organized Government because of his or their official character or that advocates or teaches the unlawful destruction of property, which said warrant was duly, served on said alien on about the 20th day of December, 1918, which said warrant is hereto attached, marked Exhibit "B" and made a part hereof.
